author: Special Correspondent
text:
Three days ahead of Prime Minister Narendara Modi’s launch of the “Start Up India” policy, Congress said on Wednesday that the BJP government must clarify its stand on Net neutrality as the idea of “large companies” taking control of the Internet would affect the country’s start-up economy.

“There must be a clear and categorical statement from the government that it will support Net neutrality and not allow large companies to restrict access to the Internet,” said senior Congress leader and former Union Minister for Environment Jairam Ramesh. “It should be the responsibility of the government to provide Internet access to all and set a clear target date by which there will be universal Internet access to all Indians.”

Taking a dig at Prime Minister Modi’s upcoming announcement of Start Up India, Mr. Ramesh said India received $90 billion in venture capital and private equity financing for 4000 companies between 2004 and 2014, of which at least 2000 may well be start-ups.

“As usual, the Prime Minister will be claiming credit for this and repackaging what the Congress had already put in place,” he said.

Mr.Ramesh said Congress vice-president Rahul Gandhi recognised the need for creating jobs in the start-up ecosystem.

After meeting around 30 entrepreneurs in New Delhi and Bengaluru, Mr.Gandhi realised that the government should provide “all possible support” to start-up economy. “Congress will work hard to advocate for them, both with the Central government, and in the State where the party is in power,” he said.
title: BJP must clarify stand on Net neutrality: Congress
